tiles.title: Github Projects
tiles.text: Some of my cooler github projects. Made with ♥ and fuelled by coffee beans.

tiles.title: Who am i?
tiles.text: A little word or two on me.</br>Who I am, where I'm from and what I get up to.
tiles.backHTML:
Who am I?

Call me Josh. I am a software engineer hailing from Central Scotland.

I like coffee a little bit too much and as a result of this I consistently find myself counter balancing the caffeine content by writing clean and efficient code.

You’ll usually find me at the gym, breaking something (and then fixing it) or knee deep in a personal project.

This websites current purpose is to showcase some of the interesting things I’ve done. You can find a few links and demonstrations of my work displayed on this website.

Speaking of work, I am currently positioned as a middleware engineer for the NatWest group.

tiles.title: p5Gravitation
tiles.text: Manipulate gravity with your mouse, coded using the p5.js library.
tiles.backHTML:
p5Gravitation

Move the mouse or a finger around and the gravity will follow.

Scroll the wheel or adjust the top slider to vary the gravity offset.

Source code is available here.

tiles.title: jsTetris
tiles.text: A basic implementation of Tetris, coded in Python using Pygame, compiled to JavaScript using Pyjs with Pyjsdl.
tiles.backHTML:
jsTetris

Keyboard controls are as follows:

KeyAction
left arrowmove left
right arrowmove right
zrotate left
xrotate right
down arrowsoft drop
spacehard drop
ppause
rrestart

Use the buttons to the right of the grid if you lack a keyboard.

Source code is available here.

tiles.title: p5Pong
tiles.text: A simple Pong clone, coded using the p5.js library.
tiles.backHTML:
p5Pong

Move the mouse or a finger around and the left paddle will follow.

Tap inside the game window to start playing.

Source code is available here.

tiles.title: About this website
tiles.text: Some information on the rubber bands and string holding this website together.
tiles.backHTML:
About this website

This website is currently self hosting inside a kubernetes cluster on an Intel NUC, pictured right. It features an Intel quad core i5 clocked at 1.6Ghz and 8gb of memory, packed tightly into a tiny little footprint that can fit in the palm of your hand.

The website itself is written mostly in jQuery. It takes JSON files as input and uses the information contained within to build up the page HTML, the end result of this process is an array of customised tiles.

As you can see from the statistics, the server is usually doing a fat lot of nothing. It does however host a surprising number of services, some of which were home grown! For example roomAPI drives my home automation and livestats is powering the table to your right.
